*** UPDATED ***  Cry of Fear is an interesting game not because of how it's done, but the fact that it's the only true survival-horror title we'll ever get in maybe a decade or so.  The team that made this game also made the Afraid of Monsters mod for Half-Life, which some such as myself feel this was an improvement over it. The atmosphere in itself is just dark, metallic, tense, and irks danger more often than not. The way the world is built around this is pretty damn good too, it does it right.  Unlike Afraid of Monsters where ammunition worked in the same way as Half-Life, this game does it tradionally, with there being a magazine counter rather than total rounds in reserve; any time you reload you dump all the rounds in the last mag, no ifs ands or butts about it, it's gone.

Cry of Fear is a first person and co-op horror game that was formerly a mod for Half Life 1. You play as Simon, a disturbed man that gets hit by a car and wakes up in an alley. As you wander aimlessly through the dark Scandinavian night, you get attacked by vairous monsters and demons that represent your life before and after the accident. Throuout the game, you encounter many disturbing hallucinations, that progressively get more disturbing and dangerous as the game progresses. This game is a psychological horror, and only the bravest can witstand the entire game to its brutal conclusion. The game has multiple endings, each one having a slightly different scenario, thirty unlockables, several custom campaigns, and a follow up co-op campaign, along with a custom co-op campaign. This game is dark, disturbing, and atmospheric.And it explains some of the things that people might experience after suffering from traumatic experiances. Sadly, the developers aren't making any more updates for it.

Cry Of Fear does one thing and it does it extremly well. It builds tension. The best part is that it dose this in a way no other horror genre game has done to date. Most atmospheric horor games build tension by letting your brain do a lot of the work. They place you in uneasy environments and don't rely on jump scares. Games like Silent Hill and Amnesia immediately spring to mind.  Cry of Fear is too good for that old way. They took the novel approach of building tension by making it phycologicly draining to even play the game. It took 50 minutes of menu clicking and server setting up to even start to think about launching the actual game. All the while your brain is churning and building that tension 'will this game be worth the pain?' 'What horrors could this agonizing process result in?'  The answer is that you will not be able to set up a server and the game will crash. The scary bit was you just wasted an hour of your life... NOTHING is free

You play as a depressed, self-harming boy named Simon, who goes through a variety of locations where both his physical stamina and mental stability are put to the test as he tries to return home. As you progress through the game, you begin to realize how the sheer insanity of the enemies actually reflect on Simon's very thoughts and emotions.  You have to go through this game assuming that something is going to pop out at you from where you are trying to go, or break down the door that you're directly in front of. This means that to progress, you will either need quick reflexes from the start, or you will have to employ trial and error very frequently.  There are a few issues in this game, one being that if you open a note that you stored, or even sometimes when you are reading the map in the park, the game will get stuck on it, and you will be forced to reload the most recent game save to escape the screen. Additionally, the collision experienced here is almost game-breaking; there were several instances where it took 20+ minutes in one location because of awkward placement of objects and/or enemies. The absolute darkness and apparently broken gamma/brightness adjustment controls also had me navigating through moving along walls for most of the game, especially underwater.  I recommend playing this game on 'Easy' difficulty on your first playthrough if you don't want to get incredibly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off, as I played it on 'Normal' and I'm genuinely surprised that I beat this game. There are little provisions for ammo and health, but when there are, they will either easily be overlooked because of their placement in seemingly insignificant locations, or they will be placed in plain sight, but only because you are about to REALLY need them.  The horror of the game itself was initially frightening, but only because it was unfamiliar. The jump-scares of the game quickly changed from shocking to annoying, as the same scares repeated themselves over and over and over again. The appearance of the enemies along with the general atmosphere of the game was more creepy than it was scary, but it did have a nice effect on the tensions in the game.  Why do I recommend this game?: Only because the storyline and the existence of the enemies have a very intriguing and surprising correlation, which you slowly find out as you progress through the game. Cry of Fear is full of jump-scares, but it is also full of cheap, unfair, and broken mechanics that make higher difficulties mind-numbingly frustrating. CoF is a horror shooter where you play as a young man who after having an accident on your way home you are awaken to a deserted town filled with horrific monsters and unanswered questions. While trying to survive this monster infastation you are also trying to figure out what has actually happened and if anything of this is real.  The game succeeds in the balance between psychological horror and jumpscares. There are several of them but at the right moment. The level design is very diverse with creepy atmosphere.Seriously, for a game thats so old (Half Life) the creators deserve such credit for making this game look so good. From abandoned asylums to dark corridors (I will never forget the segment with the flares), haunted forests and many more, there are clearly references to other horror games in some of them. If there's anything I've learned about horror games, it's that you're going to get scared. I started playing Cry of Fear knowing this, but quickly realized my depth of knowledge on fear was certaintly skewed a bit. It's a game that surprises you, forces you to stay calm and collected in moments where you're low on ammunition and/or fighting very menacing/pants-wettingly frightening enemies.  While Amnesia took survival horror and turned it into a franchise of special, more intuitive games, Cry of Fear acts as a more modest game, using the simple Source engine from Valve and turning it into the building blocks of an in-depth FPS experience. The development of the game is so advanced from its state as a Source mod that you can't really tell that the same engine was used for Half-Life 1.  The story, both multiplayer and single-player, is both extremely well made and naturally the most terrifying thing I've ever seen in a game past the story of Outlast, another original survival game that is more based on stealth and is without weapons. Sadly, neither is found in Cry of Fear, where ammunition is a necesity and every enemy is one that you are REQUIRED to slay to pass through.  In review, this game is amazing, and anyone with a heart-problem should steer clear of it AT ALL COSTS.

I have played Residents Evil, SCP, Slender, Exmortis, and many others. All of those gave me scares and thrills but I garentee you that all of those are mere childs play compared to this masterpiece. Cry of Fear is probably one of my favorite games of all time (and it is way too different and independent to be considered a mod anymore). Its probably because it has everything that I think should be in a game of its type and does it amazingly. You play as Simon, a depressed Swedish boy as he makes his way through a night in Stockholm. The city however has twisted into a hellish nightmare in which disturbing creatures lurk in the darkness waiting to kill you at any moment. The game's beauty lies in how well its made. Even though you are given powerful weapons you still feel helpless. All of the enemies are menacing, but most of them are easy to defeat. The scares and disturbing images will haunt you long after you've shut down you're computer. Another thing this game does amazingly is the story. This one takes the cake for my favorite horror game because it combines all of the great things I talked about above with a mature and emotionally charged storyline that will have you questioning you're own views on life. With multiple endings and rewarding unlockables, you will play this game numerous times. Load it up, turn off the lights, put on your headphones, and Team Psykaller will tell you a tale of depression, love, despair, fear, and a boy just trying to find his way home.   5 out of 5

What can I say that has not already been said about this game? It is a one of a kind experience...Granted I am only 3 hrs into it(about half way), I will say this game is Scary as Hell, If you truly allow yourself to become absorbed into it's world....Let's just say that playing it in the dark with Headphones on is a must...(be warned, if playing on a laptop in bed next to your wife late at night, your likely to get a pillow in the face after swearing from some of the scares!)  The pros -good, standard control setup -Great soundtrack -The overall Ambiance is spot-on -Interesting story(so far) -Scary as Hell  The Cons -outdated graphics (I would truly love to see a major publishing company pick this up and give it a major graphical overhaul) which at some points, this makes some of the 'Monsters' look kinda goofy looking -The voice actor's english is a little rough in parts -some of the puzzles can be a little frustrating -some of the jumps (um, why are we jumping?) can be frustrating, due to the level design (here is a hint-REMEMBER you can crouch, so try combining the crouch with the jump....Honestly, before I tried this, I got hung up in the opening act for 15mins!) -load time when going into a new section... -Scary as Hell -Getting a pillow in my face from my wife   My final Thought-Even after all of these minor to medium detractors, Cry of Fear is Honestly a superb game that truly should not be missed, if you enjoy a physcological thriller. Best of all it is FREE (which makes all the cons bareable....well all of them, except the pillow)  Enjoy!   Update 1/23/15-After another 6 hous into the game...I chose NOT to finish Cry of Fear...My feelings towards this game have drasticly changed....up until chapter 4, this game is pretty straight forward, not that complex, decent puzzles, superb ambiance over all a pretty good game as my original review stated...Then Chapter 4 came....  The problems with chapter 4....  #1-So far up to this point the game is pretty straight forward, it is in chapter 4(which honsetly is the longest chapter, about 10x as long as previous chapters) where you will spend a great deal of time running back and forth, and all the way around, and then back again, oh and then back agin to this other part for this item that you had to leave over there to go on, but now you need it, so back again we go, but we are somewhere new, so how do we get back again? if this doesn't sound so utterly confusing, let me tell you the best part....There is NO MAP/HUD...You have to relie on the exteremly vague maps that you find in random places...There is NOTHING saying 'hey go this way to get here' Your best bet is to take a picture of the computer screen when you have the map up with your phone(your real life phone) so you can reference back to it, to help from getting completely lost...and if that was not frustrating enough.........  #2-The Jumps....This is by far the most absolutely frustrating part of Cry of Fear...Some of the Jumps, in Chapter 4 are downright cruel...Like I said earlier, why the **** are we jumping? When did this become Tomb Raider?..............Honestly if the jumps where taken out it would in NO WAY detract from the overall enjoyment of the game....Having platform jumping in this game, is honestly just an attempt to frustrate the player, which truly is NOT needed......  My updated Final thoughts on Cry of Fear--Cry of fear started out as a great game, great ambiance, intriguing story,& Scary as Hell......Then in the middle of the game, it Totally Tanks...& you are left with one of 2 options, to continue on, for the umpteenth hundred time after dying(usually from failing to land the jump) or to give up.....After this game pushed me to the edge continuiously I had enough...& decided to watch the walkthrough of Cry of Fear on Youtube...Let's just say after watching ALL 7 endings, this game is throughly messed up.....I will say this, It wasn't what I was expecting....  In closing--I am changing my recommendation on this game to 'NO'....mainly due to Chapter 4 being a mess...if you survive chapter 4, it truly doesn't get much better...It continues on the downward spiral of frustration and repeated back and forth trogging....Ultimately I recommend just finding the walkthrough on Youtube(without commentary for the best experience) if you want to see the story & what's going on..... While I was originally put off because of it's origins as a GldSrc horror mod (had some crappy experiences in the past), I've grown to appreciate this little game. The atmosphere is very heavy, even for a horror game. The voice acting is decent, but nothing astounding in my book. Be warned though, the game kicks your ♥♥♥. The only way to heal yourself is through morphine syringes and those are few and far between. This, combined with a lack of console command cheats and saving only taking place at designated casette recorders (in the highest difficulty you have to also spend a casette to save) will lead to a lot of time being spent covering lost ground after respawning. It may take a cheap blow with jumpscaring enemies here and there, but excels in brewing dread. I found myself hardly tapping my keyboard, constantly trying to peek around corners so a monster couldn't get the jump on me. It borrowed a Doom 3 mechanic in which you must equip a light source in one hand to use it, often making players choose between sight and defense. Dual wielding exists, but one handed weapons have slower and less accurate attacks when used in conjunction of other one handed items. One big gripe I have with the game, though, is the prevalence of bugs in the standalone port. Many, many people complain that the co-op is unplayable and those with 64 bit computers will likely have to download a third-party patch to ensure stability, lest you crash before even getting to the first save point. As long as your system meets the requirements, download the single stability patch, and play the single player game, you can still get hours of play time with little issue.
